Dependent Variables: comparison between long term abstinent alcoholics and  HC
Effect of AUD: long-term abstinent alcoholics (LTAA) had higher resting state synchrony (RSS) than HC
Sample Size: LTAA: 40 (females: 42.5% (none MDD females: 33.33%; none MDD males: 66.66%; lifetime in remission females: 72.72%; lifetime in remission males: 27.27%; current MDD females: 25%; current MDD males: 75%), age: 48.8 (non MDD female age: 44±4; none MDD males age: 50±5; lifetime in remission females age: 52±6; lifetime in remission males age: 36±1; current MDD females age: 51±7; current MDD males age: 49±8), HC: 69 (females: 49.28%, age: 49±8 (males age: 50±7))
Sample Characteristics: LTAA: met DSM-IV criteria for lifetime alcohol dependence, but not for lifetime abuse or dependence on any other drugs of abuse were abstinent from alcohol and drugs for between 75.6 and 1678.6 weeks (mean = 367.9 ± 386.6 weeks); HC: were between 35.3 and 60.9 years of age (mean = 48.6 years), NSAC had a lifetime drinking average of less than 30 standard drinks per month with no periods of drinking more than 60 drinks per month, and no lifetime history of alcohol or substance abuse or dependence
Notes: LTAA: long-term abstinent alcoholics (8 with current major depressive disorder (MDD) and 32 without (none: 21, lifetime in remission: 11)); 35 -59years old, avarage 368 weeks without alcohol; hard to get effect sizes from the manuscript - graphs dont clearly show which belongs where

Sample Characteristics: LTAA: met DSM-IV criteria for lifetime alcohol dependence, but not for lifetime abuse or dependence on any other drugs of abuse were abstinent from alcohol and drugs for between 75.6 and 1678.6 weeks (mean = 367.9 ± 386.6 weeks); HC: were between 35.3 and 60.9 years of age (mean = 48.6 years), NSAC had a lifetime drinking average of less than 30 standard drinks per month with no periods of drinking more than 60 drinks per month, and no lifetime history of alcohol or substance abuse or dependence

Independent Variable: gradient of connectivity between frontal regions and striatum (PeaCoG)
Parcellation: neuromorphometrics (NMM) atlas, PCA to create gradient
Effect of AUD: significantly lower values in AUD group (more ventral striatum connectivity than dorsal striatum)
Sample Characteristics: Patients were recruited from the Central Institute of Mental Health (CIHM) inpatient clinic. Trained psychologists diagnosed alcohol addiction based on the International Classification of Disease (ICD-10) and the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-IV).
Notes: AASE: Alcohol Abstinence Self?Efficacy Scale, ADS: Alcohol Dependence Scale, AUQ: Alcohol Urge Questionnaire

Independent Variable: 10 FCs between 5 central execution network nodes: bilateral dorsolateral prefrontal cortex, bilateral posterior parietal cortex, and the paracingulate gyrus
Parcellation: ICA - 5 core nodes of the central executive network
Sample Characteristics: alcohol use was assessed using the Alcohol Use Questionnaire (AUQ), AUD drinkers met criteria for DSM-IV-TR alcohol dependence at T1 and low-risk drinkers were determined to be at low risk for developing an AUD based on NIAAA criteria
Notes: SD approximately ± 1.9 (see prestudy: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6739688/); also investigated longitudinal development of binge drinking, stronger FC between R dorsolateral prefrontal cortex and L posterior parietal cortex predicted greater increase in binge drinking

Notes: SD approximately ± 1.9 (see prestudy: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6739688/); also investigated longitudinal development of binge drinking, stronger FC between R dorsolateral prefrontal cortex and L posterior parietal cortex predicted greater increase in binge drinking

Sample Characteristics: BD was defined as having?4/5 drinks (a drink was defined as a 360 mLcan/bottle of beer, a 120 mL glass of wine, a 360 mL can/bottle of wine cooler, or a 37 mL shot of liquor straight or in a mixed drink) for women/men on a single occasion. The BD group comprised 149 adults who reported BD at least once a week for the last 12 months.
Notes: BD = binge-drinkers, compared task and rest FC, different classifiers, different ROI#: 4/7 tasks were better than rest; GCN was the best model for almost all scenarios; 116 ROIs performed the best

Parcellation: insula seed ROIs (4 ROIs, anterior L+R, posterior L+R)
Sample Characteristics: AUDIT: AUD 28.91±5.64, HC 2.61±2.26; Age ~40; 53% of AUD smokers, 1% in HC only! AUD abstinent after withdrawal
Notes: The study is somewhat confounded by smoking. Smoking appears to enhence the differences between L anterior insula and cerebellum. Also observed higher DTI FA of tracts from the anterior insula and more grey matter volume of the insula in HCs.

Parcellation: insula seed ROIs (4 ROIs, anterior L+R, posterior L+R)

Independent Variable: average alcohol consumption per day in the last year
Dependent Variables: FC nucleus accumbens - dorsolateral prefrontal cortex
Effect of AUD: negative association with average alcohol consumption per day
Sample Characteristics: inclusion criteria were: right-handedness; sufficient comprehension of German; at least two drinking occasions during the three months before inclusion, thereby ensuring inclusion of social drinking behavior in the study sample; normal or corrected-to-normal vision
Notes: 199 heathy male 18 year old adolescents, 143 at follow-up

Dependent Variables: statistical test of difference in AUD vs HC
Effect of AUD: greater average connectivity in moderate to heavy drinkers (females only)
Sample Size: no to low drinkers: 76 (females: 50%, age females: 17.7±2.0, age males: 17.9±1.9), moderate to heavy drinkers: 76 (females: 50%, age females: 18.1±2.0, age males: 18.2±1.7)
Sample Characteristics: whole sample: 584 no to low drinkers, 130 moderate to heavy drinkers; Adolescents 12-21 from NCADA, no-to-low drinkers according to the national institute of alcohol abuse and alcoholism (NIAAA) guidelines for risky drinking, the remaining 130 youth that exceeded the drinking criteria but did not exceed marijuana and nicotine exposure criteria were classified as moderate-to-heavy drinkers, none of the moderate-to-heavy drinkers participants met DSM 5 criteria for AUD at baseline observation
Notes: longitudinal study with focus on gender differences in adolescents

Sample Size: no to low drinkers: 76 (females: 50%, age females: 17.7±2.0, age males: 17.9±1.9), moderate to heavy drinkers: 76 (females: 50%, age females: 18.1±2.0, age males: 18.2±1.7)
Sample Characteristics: whole sample: 584 no to low drinkers, 130 moderate to heavy drinkers; Adolescents 12-21 from NCADA, no-to-low drinkers according to the national institute of alcohol abuse and alcoholism (NIAAA) guidelines for risky drinking, the remaining 130 youth that exceeded the drinking criteria but did not exceed marijuana and nicotine exposure criteria were classified as moderate-to-heavy drinkers, none of the moderate-to-heavy drinkers participants met DSM 5 criteria for AUD at baseline observation
Notes: longitudinal study with focus on gender differences in adolescents

Relevant Region A: dorsal anterior cingulate cortex/dorsomedial prefrontal cortex
Effect of AUD: greater alcohol use was related to reduced nodal degree
Sample Characteristics: Uk Biobank, longitudinal, AUDIT score 5.18±4.19
